I'm 9 years late, but Michael will reach the top on day 28. At the end of every night, Michael Squirrel will end up at a number of feet equal to whatever day it is. On day 1, he climbs 3, drops 2, so ends up at 1. On day 10, he'll start at 9 (the total from the night before), climb 3 to hit 12, but drop 2 to hit 10, equal to the day-number. So on day 27, he starts at 26 (the total from the night before), climbs 3 (to 29), then drops 2 (ending at 27). So the daytime of day 28, he'll climb 3, hitting 30 as a total. 10 days has 9 nights
first day, 3 up and 2 down = 1 feet
second day, 3 up and 2 down + 1 feet from before = 2 feet
third day, 3 up and 2 down + 2 feet from before = 3 feet
etc.
27th day, 3 up and 2 down + 26 feet from before = 27 feet
28th day, 3 up, it's not nighttime yet and reaches 30 feet.
28 days.

This does not apply above the northern arctic circle or below the south arctic circle, due day and night can vary over seasons.

I'm about to blow all your minds right now, it isn't 27 days.
You see he climbs 3 feet during the day, so what is he doing with the rest of this time? My guess would be sleeping and the occasional eat stop, since what else is there to do? He cant leave the tree because then he would have to start all over again. Every night he initially falls 2 feet, then what does he do? Surely after sleeping all day he should do some climbing (it never says he doesn't climb during the night), and we know his average climb speed is 3 feet per 12 hours (assuming day and night are equal length which they arent but we dont know where he lives so its the best we've got.) So during the night he must also climb an additional 3 feet with powernaps in between.
Do the math and its on the 8th day that he reaches the top.

Disclaimer for those who failed to think before they tried to outsmart me: If you are going to say I'm wrong because it uses day to describe a 24 hour period rather than the time during which the sun is out, then it still might not be 27 because he might fall 2 feet before he climbs the third foot of that day.

The riddle says "every day he climbs 3 feet" (not, 'in the day')
'A day' is a 24 hour time period which restarts at midnight. 
It then says "at night he falls 2 feet" - 'Night' is a term used for the darkened hours within the time period of the day. 
This means that Michael actually climbs 5 feet during the 'day-time' hours of the day, then falls 2 feet during the 'night-time' hours of the day, resulting in a climb of 3 feet over the whole day.
It should therefore take him 10 days to reach the top of the tree.

And the fourth son is called Michael of course.

28 days. Here's how you do it using math. On the first day, he climbed 3 ft, and on the 2nd day, he climbed a total of 4 ft since he fell 2 ft last night. Notice the difference between the 2 days is 1. Each day after the 1st is found by just adding 1 ft to the previous day. So the formula for this sequence is 3+(n-1)1=30: 3 is the number of feet he climbed the 1st day, 1 is how much higher he climb per day, n-1 is the number of the day subtracted by the 1st day, and 30 is the height of the tree.

its really 28 days and 27 nights. If he climbs 3 feet during the day and falls 2 feet during the night, then he will overall have climbed 1 foot in 1 day. Most people will think that because of this, it will take 30 days. However you're forgetting that he climbs 3 feet during the day BEFORE he falls 2 feet during night. It should be obvious that 28 days is also a correct answer as others have stated.

...cont
Finally, the case where he never reaches the top.
It states he climbs 3 feet every day (24 hrs) which could be a minimum gain.
But he could fall 2 feet each time he falls but only at night and he could fall more than once each night and thus he would make no progress day after day, never reaching the top.

...cont
If the time it took him was measured by someone at the equator 10044 days (27.5 x 365.25) would be accounted for. There could also be a one day discrepancy depending on whether or not he started on or immediately after a leap-year.

cont...

...cont

The case of 10044 days.
The location of the tree is not specified, nor is the location at which the number of days is measured from.
Taking worst case, the tree is located at the North Pole, where dawn to dawn cycles can last 6 months and that Michael climbs 3 feet each cycle and falls 2 feet each night cycle. If he started at dawn climbed 27 cycles and on the 28th cycle he decided to do his climbing at dusk. This would be 27 cycles plus 6 months.
cont...

...cont.

The case of the one day climb.
So Michael could start climbing at dawn, climb 3 feet and stop to rest. Since it is still daylight he repeats this until he reaches the top all in 1 day.

cont...

Due to the imprecise nature on the English language and important details left out, I am going to give 3 answers. Each are correct.

Michael could reach the top in 1 day, as long as 27.5 years (10044 days), or never.

The word day can mean 24 hrs but it can also means daylight hours as well as the time between 2 successive points in the day cycle such as dawn or dusk.

Hm. I suppose you *could* take the second 'day' that forms the basis of the question as 'hours of daylight', at a stretch, it'd be used like that in the phrase 28 days and 27 nights. Which would mean 28 would be correct. So the real answer is that *both* 27.5(ish) & 28 are right depending on which definition of day is utilised. Usually in questions of 'how many days?' the former, a 24hr period, would be by far the more usual meaning though. The son's name is Michael since he is the 4th son.
